posts.cooked:
This year team 955 has decided to move away from building a custom wcd and will instead use the kit bot. This is primarily because of limited fabrication capabilities this year and less experienced students.

In preparation for this, our design team created a full model of the kitbot with bumpers, and a “practice” eboard. The eboard is intended to get the robot driving as soon as possible before our final eboard placement/design is finished.

The model can be found here: onshape model

Feedback would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Looks like a pretty clean build–your bumper blocks are way more interesting than our approach.

This is great practice for the season, though if you’re looking at using the AM14U4 next year you may want to take advantage of the configurable one in the MKCad library .  Being able to blast through configurations quickly really frees up a lot of labor that can be used to design other parts of your robot.

However you go about it, good luck this year!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
I absolutely love it.

Personally I’m not a fan of the stock wheels due to comparatively lower traction and spoke breaking issues. You can switch to colsons fairly easily for more grip and robustness with similarly low maintenance. Can also switch to treaded wheels, but that requires work to cut and replace treads.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
AdamHeard:

Personally I’m not a fan of the stock wheels due to comparatively lower traction and spoke breaking issues.

I’m curious when the spoke breaking issues you’re remembering happened; AndyMark has had two notable revisions of the 6" HiGrip wheel over the years (compare the current am-0940b to the older am-0940a and it’s obvious how much beefier the webbing is).  I know how easy it is for us old-timers to have memories run together; I realized this afternoon that kids who played FIRST Power Up have all graduated.

Since moving back to AM14U flavors for 2019, we haven’t had any breakages–and that includes 2019 where we had to replace clicking bearings before off-seasons because we were sending a tail-heavy robot off of level 2 of the habitat nearly every match for two regionals.  (And I’ll be honest, having worked the AndyMark booth for three Championship events when am-0940a existed I don’t remember any notable breakage help calls then either.)

The existing Colson options are not tailored great to the AM14U-style chassis–you’ll need hex bore ones in some places, you’ll need to press hubs in for others, then the belt pulleys will need their own solution figured out, and gah I hope all the spacers and Churro standoffs are still the right length.  It is a disservice to recommend that approach to a team who (and I say this with love) went 1-for-4 on district playoffs in 2018 and 2019, 0-for-2 on making PNW DCMP, and by their own admission has shrunken in resources since then.

If we get another 2016 game and the HiGrip wheels are truly of concern, I’d much sooner reach for the pneumatic wheel kits from AndyMark for a solution where my only requirement is to cut some churro to the length listed in the drawing, assemble, and then focus on problems that aren’t solved.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.cooked: Right now our plan is to stick with the stock wheels unless the game really requires something else. We think the design and fabrication effort spent in adding colsons would be better spent on improvements elsewhere. We will certainly get spare wheels though. We’ll see how they do during season.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
I couldn’t tell you the team number, but I saw hi grip spokes break at LAN 2020. I obviously don’t know which specific revision of the wheel they were running, but they were installed in an AM14U4 so likely whatever was in 2020 KOP?

The colson wheels can be integrated entirely with COTS pulleys and hubs from vexpro, and fit in the existing 3.375" wheel well.

It’s a 30 minute exercise to figure out what spacers go where, which hubs to use, etc… but just as quick to assemble past that. It’s purely a configuration exercise, NO fabrication required.

2135 ran the above colson config for 2021 offseasons (but with printed pulleys because I’m lazy, would have worked with COTS pulleys).

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan
posts.cooked:
Billfred:

Since moving back to AM14U flavors for 2019, we haven’t had any breakages–and that includes 2019 where we had to replace clicking bearings before off-seasons because we were sending a tail-heavy robot off of level 2 of the habitat nearly every match for two regionals.

Yep, 3476 switched to the upgraded HiGrips on our 2019 robot and ran them all season with no issues with breaking spokes. They kept up well through lots of practice and events.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Billfred:

I’m curious when the spoke breaking issues you’re remembering happened; AndyMark has had two notable revisions of the 6" HiGrip wheel over the years

We have broken every revision of that wheel, from ~2005 thru 2019. The later ones were perhaps more our fault for side loading (T-boning into the plywood edge of the hab ramps), but it was regularly a concern whenever they were used, and the material hides cracks fairly well.

image 1081×1389 280 KB

image 1081×1389 280 KB
Would it be something like the vex dead hub and a 6" colson like these? hub , wheel I think we’ll wait for the game to decide.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: Yup! If you solve it with 6" Colsons, you can also swap to 4" if the field allows with no change to anything except the wheel itself.
We’d also likely have to change the gear ratio though if we do 4" right? Unfortunately all the 4" colsons we have on hand are the 1/2" hex bore ones iirc.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Correct, but Andymark sells different gear sets for the toughbox mini to accommodate this.

I agree with your approach of waiting for the game, and will also stress that 6" has been a good wheel size for more than half of the recent games (and for the rest, there was little penalty to running 6").

It’s certainly good to know about the problem. We’ll fork the design and add colsons, but we’ll wait to order parts until after the game is released or maybe even after our first comp. Thanks for the help!

posts.name: Orion DeYoe
posts.cooked:
I have to agree with Billfred on this one.  While swapping wheels might be a reasonably simple upgrade to the KOP drivetrain, this is a bad recommendation to a team in this position.

Teams (in a similar position), don’t start by customizing the KOP drivetrain.  Just build it straight from the kit and focus your efforts on a scoring mechanism.  If the field has a particularly difficult obstacle or you find issues in testing, then that’s the time for customizations.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
That’s definitely a reasonable approach, but also seems like we’re making a wheel swap seem far more difficult than it is.

With 16 days to kickoff a little bit of time before the game reveal makes the post kickoff efforts just as quick and not compromise other systems.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
image 1665×1246 151 KB I like where the bumper mount design is going. I think I would try to get rid of the tubing though. Either some sort of 3D printed block if you trust it or a bent aluminum bracket. alternatively I like something that gets trapped inside the upper and lower flanges of the outer frame rail just like the KOP bumper mounts.

image 1665×1246 151 KB

image 1665×1246 151 KB
What’s the problem with the tubing? The potential issues I see with it are alignment, and rigidity (as there are only 2 rivets holding it in place).

posts.name: wilsonmw04
posts.cooked: I don’t see anything wrong with your mounts. The only thing I see is if a robot or something else get under your bumpers. They might be able to push your bolt out of the slot. Beyond that, I think it’s an effective solution.
That’s the purpose of the front/back blocks, which have a vertical screw to prevent the bumpers from being lifted up.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: I just don’t like working with short bits of tubing like that and having to use multiple brackets to mount it. Just kind of a personal preference thing. It’s giving me an idea though. might try to model it in the next couple days or so and share it here. Also I have an easy way to keep it from lifting on the outer two mounts.
